definition: to let things take their course (idiom)/to leave it to nature/laissez-faire
surname Ren/Ren County 任縣|任县[Ren2 Xian4] in Hebei

to assign/to appoint/to take up a post/office/responsibility/to let/to allow/to give free rein to/no matter (how, what etc)/classifier for terms served in office, or for spouses, girlfriends etc (as in 前任男友)
his/her/its/their/that/such/it (refers to sth preceding it)
self/oneself/from/since/naturally/surely
correct/right/so/thus/like this/-ly

sentences.english: This would wreck budgets and upset the navy and air force. So be it.
sentences.chinese: 這或許突破預算，影響海軍和空軍，任其自然。

sentences.english: We can't let things go hang.

definition: to let things take their course/to take things as they come
to let nature take its course (idiom)
to take a laissez-faire attitude
to let sb do whatever they want/to indulge/to give free reins to/to let things slide/to drift aimlessly/laissez-faire
to let (sth happen)/to allow (sb to do sth)/to submit to/to yield
to allow (sb to have his head)/to let things happen
(idiom) carefree/untroubled
to continue the same old routine/to carry on just as before/to procrastinate
(doing sth) in the right way/suitable/properly
to follow/to go along with
futile endeavor (idiom)
to take advantage of the new situation (idiom)/to make the best of new opportunities
see 拔苗助長|拔苗助长[ba2 miao2 zhu4 zhang3]
not paying attention to anything (idiom); to idle time away
to spoil things through excessive enthusiasm (idiom)
no good/not good for/not beneficial
